document.docTitle: Lincus curvatus Campos & Roell, 2017, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Description of four new species of Ochlerini from South America (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae: Discocephalinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of four new species of Ochlerini from South America (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae: Discocephalinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. The epithet refers to the curved male proctiger; Latin:
curvatus
, bend, bow, crook.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type locality.
Ecuador , Orellana , El Coca (coordinates -0.2861, -77.1016).

Holotype male. Labels : Ecuador , Orellana ,
El Coca
, Palmar del Rio ,
1-15/X/2015
, R. Asipuela col., on OxG hybrids (
Elaeis oleifera
x
Elaeis guineensis
) ( DZUP )

subSubSection.paragraph: Paratypes: 7 females, 5 males. Same data as holotype (2 females and 1 male DZUP; 5 females and 4 males UFRG).

Description. Body oval, dark brown. Head subrectangular, wider than long; punctures confluent forming wrinkles, denser between eyes; mandibular plates reflexed, little longer than clypeus and converging towards the apex, not touching each other before clypeus. Width of each eye equal to half the interocular width. Ocelli placed close to the lateral margins of head and posterior to an imaginary line connecting the posterior limit of eyes. Antennae with five antennomeres bearing thin setae, denser on fourth and fifth antennomeres; dark brown except for the base of fifth antennomere yellowish. Proportion of antennomeres: I<II<III<IV<V. Antennal tubercles visible from above, acute apically. Labium long arising posterior to an imaginary line connecting the anterior margins of eyes, reaching the sixth abdominal segment. Proportion of labium segments: I<II>III>IV. Labrum sinuous, bent frontwards.

Pronotum trapezoidal, wider than long at midline; punctures confluent, forming wrinkles, cicatrices with a median low tubercle. Anterior margin concave, anterolateral margins sinuous, reflexed and emarginated at humeral angles. Anterolateral pronotal margins expanded in obtuse angle posterior to pronotal lobes. Pronotal lobes spatulate, rounded, juxtaposed to posterior margin of eyes. Humeral angles not produced. Scutellum longer than wide, surpassing imaginary line connecting middle of each connexival segment V; punctures denser on disc, forming wrinkles; subtle yellowish spot at middle of anterior margin. Frenal margins longer than postfrenal margins. Corium longer than scutellum, reaching connexival segment VI, punctures denser than on scutellum, not forming wrinkles; subtle yellowish spot at apex of radial vein; membrane not surpassing the apex of abdomen. Membrane of corium arcuate cut in males. Pro- and metasternum flat, mesosternum carinate. Pro-, meso-, and metapleura sparsely punctured, metapleural evaporatorium extending less than half way to lateral margin of metapleuron. Peritreme spout-shaped. Tibiae sulcate dorsally and laterally, bearing lateral and ventral setae, these denser at apex. Third metatarsomere dorsally concave in males and females.
Abdomen ventrally convex at midline, thinly punctured; tricobothria lateral to imaginary line connecting lateral margin of spiracles.

Genitalia. Pygophore. Dorsal rim sinuous, projected mesially over base of segment X ( Fig. 2 E, dr); lateral margins bearing setae. Posterolateral angles ( Figs. 2 E, F, pa) rounded, with two dorsal laminar projections from the superior layer of ventral rim, bordered in black ( Fig. 2 E, p2, p1): the first lateral, triangular in dorsal view placed near the distal margin of the posterolateral angle ( Fig. 2 E, p2), and the second mesial, triangular in posterior view. This second projection continues ventrally to a third one, in the shape of an arched carina converging to the inferior layer of ventral rim ( Fig. 2 G, p3). Ventral rim V-shaped ( Fig. 2 F, vr), bearing setae. Parameres small, trapezoid ( Fig. 3 E–H), covered by segment X. Segment X quadrangular and membranous at base, projected posteriorly and ventrad in cylinder, spatulate with rounded expansion at apex. The segment X curves to the right ( Fig. 2 E–G). Phallus double drop shaped in dorsal view ( Fig. 3 A); phallotheca strongly convex dorsally, limit between phallotheca and vesica tenuous ( Fig. 3 A–D, ph); vesica expanded dorsodistally into a scimitar blade-shape ( Fig. 3 C, v), in apposition to the tubular, sclerotized ductus seminis distalis ( Fig. 3 C, ds). Secondary gonopore round.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
, male. A–C, dorsal, ventral and lateral view respectively. D, head and pronotum, dorsal. E–G, pygophore, dorsal, ventral and posterior view respectively. Abbreviations: dr, dorsal rim; p1, projection 1; p2, projection 2; p3, projection 3; pa, posterolateral angle; X, segment X. Scale bars: A–D = 1mm; E–G = 0.5mm.

FIGURE 3.
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
, male, A–C, phallus, dorsal, ventral and lateral view respectively. D, photograph of the phallus in lateral view. E–G, right paramere, dorsal, ventral and lateral view respectively. H, photograph of the paramere in ventral view. Abbreviations: ds, ductus seminis distalis; ph, phalloteca; v, vesica. Scale bars = 0.5mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Genitalia. Genital plates sparsely punctured; gonocoxites VIII and laterotergites IX wrinkled ( Fig. 4 D, gcVIII, laIX). Gonocoxites VIII subtriangular, longer than wide, sutural margins straight, juxtaposed, posterior margins convex ( Fig. 4 D, gcVIII). Laterotergites VIII trapezoid, wider than long, mesial and posterior margins subrectilinear ( Fig. 4 D, laVIII). Exposed portion of gonocoxites IX lozenge, small ( Fig. 4 D, gcIX). Exposed portion of laterotergites IX oval, not attaining the band uniting laterotergites VIII, mesial margins juxtaposed covering segment X ( Fig. 4 D, laIX). Gonocoxites IX v-shaped ( Fig. 5 A, C, gcIX), large and strongly convex. Gonapophyses IX weakly sclerotized, bent posteriorly ( Fig. 5 A, C, gpIX), lateral portion rugose and bearing conical projections ( Fig. 5 A, C, cp). Ring sclerites absent. Secondary thickenings of gonapophyses IX large, located medially on folds of gonapophyses IX. Thickening of vaginal intima broadly ogival, wider than long ( Figs. 5 A, C, vi). Orificium receptaculi located on apex of vaginal intima ( Fig. 5 A, C, or). Vesicular area of the ductus receptaculi about five or six times longer than the combined length of pars intermedialis and capsula seminalis; median duct ( Fig. 5 A, md) fusiform at proximal end. Pars intermedialis twice the length of capsula seminalis ( Fig. 5 A, B, pi, cs). Capsula seminalis globose, bearing three wide processes ( Fig. 5 A, C, cs). Anterior (= distal) annular ridge directed to pars intermedialis; posterior (= proximal) annular ridge perpendicular to pars intermedialis.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
, female, A–C, dorsal, ventral and lateral view respectively. D, genital plates, posterior. Abbreviations: gc VIII, gonocoxites VIII; gcIX, gonocoxites IX; laVIII, laterotergites VIII; la IX, laterotergites IX. Scale bars = 1mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments.
Lincus curvatus
is described in Lincus based on the overall body shape, the shape of head and pronotum, the presence of anterolateral pronotal lobes, and the structure of the genitalia in both sexes. In the key for the species of Lincus by Rolston (1983) the new species keys either to
Lincus lamelliger Breddin
for specimens with short pronotal lobes ( Fig. 2 A, D), or to
Lincus subuliger Breddin
for specimens with long pronotal lobes ( Fig. 4 A). These species,
L. lamelliger
and
L. subuliger
, are in the “big-eyed” informal group of species (sensu Rolston, 1983 ), characterized by the width of each eye equal or greater than one-half of the interocular width, as also seen in the new species. Also within the “big-eyed” group, the gonocoxites VIII of
L. curvatus
resemble
Lincus styliger Breddin
, the pygophore and phallus are similar to
Lincus laminatus Rolston
, while the segment X of male well projected beyond the posterior margin of pygophore and broadly expanded at apex resembles
Lincus subuliger Breddin.
L. curvatus
can be readily distinguished by the dark body color, the shape and proportions of the female genital plates, the long mesial laminar projection in the superior layer of ventral rim of pygophore, and the curved segment X of males. The shape of the hemelytral membrane in males of
L. curvatus
is also a distinctive feature, and although this kind of sexual dimorphism has never been described for other species of Lincus , we observed similar modifications in males of
Lincus lobuliger Breddin
and
Lincus securiger Breddin. Further
morphological studies are needed to clarify whether wing dimorphism occurs in other species of Lincus .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
, female, A–C, receptaculum seminis and ectodermal genital ducts, ventral. Abbreviations: cp, conical projections; cs, capsula seminalis; gcIX, gonocoxites IX; gpIX, gonapophysis IX; id, inner duct of vesicular area; md, median duct of vesicular area; od, outer duct of vesicular area; or, orificium receptaculi; pi, pars intermedialis; vi, thickening of vaginal intima. Scale bars = 0.5mm.

FIGURE 6.
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
, left hemelytrum, dorsal. A, B, male and female respectively. Scale bars = 1mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note: all specimens of
Lincus curvatus
sp. nov.
were collected on oil palms (OxG hybrids,
Elaeis oleifera
x
Elaeis guineensis
) affected by the lethal wilt (marchitez sorpresiva) disease.
